title: Who wrote the song Raghupati Raghav Raja Ram? - Quora

response.answer_text: "Raghupati Raghava" is a bhajana from Nama Ramayana written by Sri Lakshmanacharya. Gandhi tampered with the bhajana to suit his political interests. Tampered version which includes "Allah, Rahim" has been popularized by the so called “seculars” of India. Here is the original bhajana- रघुपति राघव राजाराम पतित पावन सीताराम सुंदर विग्रह मेघश्याम गंगा तुलसी शालग्राम भद्रगिरीश्वर सीताराम भगत-जनप्रिय सीताराम जानकीरमणा सीताराम जयजय राघव सीताराम English transliteration- Raghupati raghava rajaram Patita paavana sitaram Sundara vigraha meghashyam Ganga tulasi salagram Bhadra girishwara sitaram Bhagat janapriya sitaram Janaki ramana sitaram Jaya jaya raghava sitaram Tampered version by Gandhi- रघुपति राघव राजाराम, पतित पावन सीताराम सीताराम सीताराम, भज प्यारे तू सीताराम ईश्वर अल्लाह तेरो नाम, सब को सन्मति दे भगवान English transliteration of the tampered version- raghupati rāghav rājārām, patit pāvan sītārām sītārām, jai sītārām, bhaj pyāre tu sītārām īśvar allāh tero nām, sab ko sanmati de bhagavān Gandhi removed गंगा तुलसी शालग्राम because of Shalagrama's association with Vaishnavism and Hindu rituals. He removed भद्रगिरीश्वर सीताराम as the line refers to Rama as Lord of Bhadrachalam. Bhandrachalam in Andhra Pradesh is the site where a great idol temple Lord Rama exists. He removed the line सुंदर विग्रह मेघश्याम because physical description of Hindu God Rama as मेघश्याम did not go well with his monotheist formless God. He replaced it with ईश्वर अल्लाह तेरो नाम so as to clarify that his Rama had nothing to do with Hindu deity Rama. Gandhi NEVER worshiped the Hindu deity Rama. As Gandhi himself made it very clear in his Ramanavami speech, Gandhi's Rama is not the Rama of Hindu scriptures. Gandhi's "Rama" is a monotheist formless God. Excerpt from Gandhi's Sabarmati speech, 1928-  These facts hit me like a brick on my head. I now wonder did Gandhi actually say “Hey Ram!” before dying?

This song was often sung at Mahatma Gandhi’s prayer gatherings. As far as I know it was composed by Pandit Vishnu Digambar Paluskar. Different versions have been sung and I am familiar with the following tune. Let me play a brief snatch on the flute for those interested in hearing it. Please Don’t expect too much. I am just an average and self taught flute player and I had half-heartedly and half seriously picked up a bit of flute playing as a hobby in my younger days. Raghupati Raaghava Raajaraam - Clyp If you search for it on You Tube you will find many links.
